MEET YOURSELF
10 YEARS FROM NOW
Ever wonder what you'll be like when the class of'54 holds
its 10th reunion? If you started to work for one of the
Bell System companies after graduation, here's a pretty
good idea.
INTERESTING, RESPONSIBLE WORK: Perhaps a Commercial
Manager, the company's representative and spokesm
an to as
many as fifty thousand customers. Or a Transmission Engineer, helping to provide the telephone needs of an entire
state. Or a Supervisor in the Traffic Department, responsible
for the speed and quality of local and long distance service
in several cities and for the personnel relations of a large
number of employees.
WE MAKE SURE THERE ARE PLACES TO GO: The number
of college men hired is related to the number of administrative and technical positions expected to be available in the
next 10 or 15 years. It is our policy to fill these positions from
within our organization.

According to college men, Arrow "Gabanaro" is
the best-fitting sports shirt on this and every campus — with built-in comfort ... neater, smarter
lines. "Gabanaro" features a wide range of colors

in washable rayon gabardine.

ARTS, SCIENCE, BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION MD
ENGINEERING GRADUATES are among our particular needs.
The specific degree is not as important as the total effect of
your college training.

NO MATTER WHAT YOUR MILITARY STATUS, contact your
Placement Officer soon for details on the opportunities for.
employment with the Bell System.

Homewood, Baltimore, March 5, 1954

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE SIX

Coach Predicts Jay Hoopsters
Will Reach Mason-Dixon Finals
By Tom Stone, Sports Editor
LONG LOST SPIRIT RETURNS

That long lost Hopkins spirit finally made its initial appearance of this 1953-54 school year last week. At the basketball
game versus our areh-rival from up Charles Street, Loyola, a week
ago last Wednesday night, the Homewood Gymnasium was booming forth with the greatest amount of spirit shown by a partisan
srowd in many-a-moon on this campus. In return for this
revitalized spirit put forth by the Jay hoop fans, Coach Bilgrav's
quintet put on their most magnificent home performance of the
season as they turned back the Greyhounds for the first time
since the 1951 season.
GRAPPLERS FULL OF SPIRIT

It was a great feeling for this old senior to be a part of that
supporting body, and brought back memories of the good-old
.days (freshman year). Then on Friday and Saturday the
Nester tooMn the annual Mason-Dixon wrestling championships
herd this year out at Towson State Teachers College, and much to
his surprise it looked as though some of this spirit had rubbed
off on our grapplers. It was the spirit and enthusiasm of this
grand bunch of guys, who have battled through just about everything in the books to field a team, that brought Mickey Cochrane
his second Mason-Dixon championship in two tries in this, his
initial year.
The fighting spirit of the entire participating Jay squad
was actually more than all of the other teams in the tourney
tombined. All of the grapplers were out there rooting on their
teammates even after being eliminated themselves. In addition
to all of this there was a small but enthusiastic and loud bunch a
Hopkins rooters at all four sessions of the tourney. Coach
Coehrane feels as though he knows of no one that he would have
rather tied for the title than Tom Clayton's Gallaudet squad.
The reason for this is that way back in 1941 while participating
for the Devitt Prep Athletic Club of Washington Cochrane
was taught most of his wrestling knowledge by the same Tom
Playton.
PARADE TO BALTIMORE STREET

Let's hope that this spirit will no leave the Homewood campus as soon again, as it did a few years back. As a matter of
fact it would certainly be great to see another one of those mass
rallies before at least one of our lacrosse games. this year, like
the one that occurred the night prior to the Princeton game in
•
1951.
It was on that Friday night in April when over 300 (believe
3t or not) Hopkins students paraded all the 'way down to
Baltimore Street and for the last time on record made known the
fact to this city that Hopkins does have athletic teams. Just ask
any one of the present seniors who participated in that last
raemorable rally about it and I'll bet they can tell you all the
,etails. It is a memorable eveht in the minds of many of us,
and will be for many years to come. How about_ the present
study body producing something of the like, though we don't
advocate the Baltimore Street trip, before the opening lacrosse
game, Hopkins versus Virginia on April 3, to give all of you
something to look back on to' your good old days at J.H.U.I
NESTER PREDICTS

With the Winter season just about complete the time has
tome for the Nester to look into our spring schedules. From
the looks of the lacrosse contests on the slate Fred Smith should,
with any luck at all, come up with a winning season. Rutgers,
Yale, Swarthmore, and Loyola shouldn't cause too much trouble
and the stickmen should be able to salvage at least one from the
remaining five scheduled, Virginia, Princeton, Navy, Maryland,
and Mt. Washingrton.
Looking over to baseball the outlook is not nearly as bright
and the Nester figures the diamond team will have to really go

ROTC Cadets Select
Own Branches In '55
Graduating ROTC student
cadets, beginning June, 1955, will
have their choice of eight of fifteen
branches of the Army in which to
receive their commissions, Lt. Col.
Emerson F. Hurley confirmed this
week.
Graduating cadets will be reviewed by a board consisting of
Colonel Hurley, some members of
his staff, and perhaps someone
connected with the university. This
board, as of the present time, Is
still in the planning stage.
Eight Preferences
At the beginning of his third
year, the ROTC student will list
eight of his preferences of
branches for appointment. In the
determination of the eight
branches the student should base
his choice upon the content of his
curriculum, his relative academic
and leadership ratings, and his
civilian occupational and military
experience. The board's selection
of the branch will be determined
by the student's academic achievement, leadership potential, and the
branch for which he is most suited.
The branches open include:
Adjutant General's Corps, Finance
Corp s, Quartermaster Corps,

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE SIX

Coach Predicts Jay Hoopsters
Will Reach Mason-Dixon Finals
By Tom Stone, Sports Editor
LONG LOST SPIRIT RETURNS

That long lost Hopkins spirit finally made its initial appearance of this 1953-54 school year last week. At the basketball
game versus our areh-rival from up Charles Street, Loyola, a week
ago last Wednesday night, the Homewood Gymnasium was booming forth with the greatest amount of spirit shown by a partisan
srowd in many-a-moon on this campus. In return for this
revitalized spirit put forth by the Jay hoop fans, Coach Bilgrav's
quintet put on their most magnificent home performance of the
season as they turned back the Greyhounds for the first time
since the 1951 season.
GRAPPLERS FULL OF SPIRIT

It was a great feeling for this old senior to be a part of that
supporting body, and brought back memories of the good-old
.days (freshman year). Then on Friday and Saturday the
Nester tooMn the annual Mason-Dixon wrestling championships
herd this year out at Towson State Teachers College, and much to
his surprise it looked as though some of this spirit had rubbed
off on our grapplers. It was the spirit and enthusiasm of this
grand bunch of guys, who have battled through just about everything in the books to field a team, that brought Mickey Cochrane
his second Mason-Dixon championship in two tries in this, his
initial year.
The fighting spirit of the entire participating Jay squad
was actually more than all of the other teams in the tourney
tombined. All of the grapplers were out there rooting on their
teammates even after being eliminated themselves. In addition
to all of this there was a small but enthusiastic and loud bunch a
Hopkins rooters at all four sessions of the tourney. Coach
Coehrane feels as though he knows of no one that he would have
rather tied for the title than Tom Clayton's Gallaudet squad.
The reason for this is that way back in 1941 while participating
for the Devitt Prep Athletic Club of Washington Cochrane
was taught most of his wrestling knowledge by the same Tom
Playton.
PARADE TO BALTIMORE STREET

Let's hope that this spirit will no leave the Homewood campus as soon again, as it did a few years back. As a matter of
fact it would certainly be great to see another one of those mass
rallies before at least one of our lacrosse games. this year, like
the one that occurred the night prior to the Princeton game in
•
1951.
It was on that Friday night in April when over 300 (believe
3t or not) Hopkins students paraded all the 'way down to
Baltimore Street and for the last time on record made known the
fact to this city that Hopkins does have athletic teams. Just ask
any one of the present seniors who participated in that last
raemorable rally about it and I'll bet they can tell you all the
,etails. It is a memorable eveht in the minds of many of us,
and will be for many years to come. How about_ the present
study body producing something of the like, though we don't
advocate the Baltimore Street trip, before the opening lacrosse
game, Hopkins versus Virginia on April 3, to give all of you
something to look back on to' your good old days at J.H.U.I
NESTER PREDICTS

With the Winter season just about complete the time has
tome for the Nester to look into our spring schedules. From
the looks of the lacrosse contests on the slate Fred Smith should,
with any luck at all, come up with a winning season. Rutgers,
Yale, Swarthmore, and Loyola shouldn't cause too much trouble
and the stickmen should be able to salvage at least one from the
remaining five scheduled, Virginia, Princeton, Navy, Maryland,
and Mt. Washingrton.
Looking over to baseball the outlook is not nearly as bright
and the Nester figures the diamond team will have to really go
something to end up with a .500 record. The presence of Don
Manger, Clark Thompson, and Al Heck will undoubtedly hold
the cindermen.above the .500 mark in their season, and this is
a team which could walk off with another Mason-Dixon crown
for the University. John Pope and his tennis squad should
!tome up with another fine showing this year, also.

ROTC Cadets Select
Own Branches In '55
Graduating ROTC student
cadets, beginning June, 1955, will
have their choice of eight of fifteen
branches of the Army in which to
receive their commissions, Lt. Col.
Emerson F. Hurley confirmed this
week.
Graduating cadets will be reviewed by a board consisting of
Colonel Hurley, some members of
his staff, and perhaps someone
connected with the university. This
board, as of the present time, Is
still in the planning stage.
Eight Preferences
At the beginning of his third
year, the ROTC student will list
eight of his preferences of
branches for appointment. In the
determination of the eight
branches the student should base
his choice upon the content of his
curriculum, his relative academic
and leadership ratings, and his
civilian occupational and military
experience. The board's selection
of the branch will be determined
by the student's academic achievement, leadership potential, and the
branch for which he is most suited.
The branches open include:
Adjutant General's Corps, Finance
Corp s, Quartermaster Corps,

notified police Saturday morning

first inspection there was no apparent damage, though he had not
